results.title: The Sociological perspective: social class: work (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: BBC-TV, Open University and Ken Patton
results.brief_description: Compares social class positions and values of two contrasting occupations - engine drivers and architects. It shows several drivers and a London architect at work and talking about their work.

results.title: The Social welfare in Germany
results.brief_description: A comprehensive survey of the development of German welfare policy since Bismark’s time. With the Social REform law Bismark introduced for the first time compulsory insurance of workers against sickness, accidents, invalidity and poverty in old age. Also shows the full extent of the present Social Security System in Germany.

results.title: The Social drinker and the anti-social driver
results.creator_credit: Charles Cahill and Associates, Charles Cahill and Jim Tartan
results.brief_description: Statistical analysis of many automobile accidents involving drinking drivers, suggests the concept that it may not be the problem drinker that is primarily responsibile for most accidents on the road, but rather the social drinker.

results.title: The Social Climbers
results.brief_description: Society has never been so high. Mount Hauscaran, 22,604ft is the venue for one of the most bizarre formal luncheons on earth. Four men, four women, and a butler compete with the gods. White knuckle adventure; white glove etiquette; even white Anglo-Saxon morality - nothing is safe from the social climbers!

results.title: The Snowy owls of Shetland
results.creator_credit: Royal Society for the Protection of Birds and Anthony Clay
results.brief_description: The first breeding record for the snowy owls in Britain is recorded at Fetlar, in the Shetland Isles off the coast of Scotland. This film is a record of the birds whilst being guarded by the members of the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds.

results.title: The Snowy Mountains Scheme showing the Guthega Project
results.brief_description: Records the construction of a new dam and power station as part of the Snowy Mountains Scheme. Before the building of the dam could begin, a tunnel had to be constrcuted to divert the waters of the river. Blizzards, a swollen river and sub-zero temperatures did not deter the Norwegian contractors and on 23rd April 1955, the Prime Minister, Mr Menzies, officially opened the power station and operated the switch which set the turbines in motion.

results.title: The Snowy Mountains
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Land Australia with Ted Egan”.
Ted Egan takes up the Snowy Mountains story 100 years after Australia’s favourite poet, Banjo Paterson, immortalised a young mountain horseman in his epic poem, “The Man From Snowy River”. Features the pioneering development and the lifestyle of the mountain’s people, including the historic construction of the Snowy Mountains Hydro-Electric Scheme. Filmed over the four seasons, the story also includes an aerial kaleidoscope of the high country from spring to winter with spectacular displays of wild flowers and fragile alpine wilderness.

results.title: The Snowy Mountain Scheme: the first achievement
results.creator_credit: Australian Instructional Films, Jean Halliday and Lex Halliday
results.brief_description:
Episode number 17 of Series “Modern social studies”.
Reports on the initial preparations and planning in the Snowy Mountains region and the completion of the first project of the scheme - the Guthega project. Construction of the Guthega Dam and Munyang power station was begun and despite the difficulty of a cold climate, the project was completed and the power house officially opened by the Prime Minister, Mr Menzies, on 23 April 1955.

results.title: The Snowy day
results.brief_description: 4 year old Peter wakes one morning to discover the city he lives in covered in a blanket of fresh, white snow. Outside, he sees a wonderland of snowmen, snow angels and snowballs. Before going inside to get warm, he makes a snowball and puts it in his pocket for safe keeping. Before going to bed that night he checks his pockets and discovers that it has melted. That night he dreams that all the snow has melted away, only to wake up and find fresh snow falling. Based on the book by Ezra Jack Keats and narrated by Jane Harvey. Winner of the Caldecott Medal in 1976 for the most distinguished picture book for children.

results.title: The Snowy day
results.creator_credit: Weston Woods Studios, Mal Wittman and Morton Schindel
results.brief_description: The silent wonder of city snow and Peter’s delight in it as he slides down snow mountains and takes a snowball home in his pocket are told in exquisite collages that reflect the sparkling quality of snow and the contrasting warmth of the home and family. Narrated by Jane Harvey.
